title: How to turn protest into powerful change - Eric Liu

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary goal of protest, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: To generate lasting positive change by itself

options.label: B
options.text: To topple dictators and create a power vacuum

options.label: C
options.text: To mobilize voters and create a more inclusive government

options.label: D
options.text: To raise awareness about social issues

multiple-choice.question: What was the outcome of the Arab Spring protests in the Middle East?

options.label: A
options.text: The establishment of stable democracies

options.label: B
options.text: The rise of militant and violent groups

options.label: C
options.text: The return of dictators to power

options.label: D
options.text: The creation of a unified regional government

multiple-choice.question: What are the three core strategies for peacefully turning awareness into action and protest into durable political power?

options.label: A
options.text: Expanding the frame of the possible, choosing a defining fight, and using social media

options.label: B
options.text: Expanding the frame of the possible, choosing a defining fight, and finding an early win

options.label: C
options.text: Mobilizing voters, casting ballots, and understanding government

options.label: D
options.text: Protesting, boycotting, and petitioning

multiple-choice.question: What does it mean to "expand the frame of the possible"?

options.label: A
options.text: To accept the status quo and work within existing boundaries

options.label: B
options.text: To challenge conventional politics and imagine alternative solutions

options.label: C
options.text: To focus on a single issue and ignore other problems

options.label: D
options.text: To give up on creating change and accept defeat

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of choosing a defining fight?

options.label: A
options.text: To create conflict and division

options.label: B
options.text: To set the terms of a debate and capture the essence of the change you want

options.label: C
options.text: To avoid controversy and maintain the status quo

options.label: D
options.text: To distract from other issues and create a diversion

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a successful defining fight mentioned in the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: The fight for a $10 minimum wage

options.label: B
options.text: The fight for a $15 minimum wage

options.label: C
options.text: The fight for a $20 minimum wage

options.label: D
options.text: The fight for a universal basic income

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of seeking an early win?

options.label: A
options.text: To create a sense of complacency and reduce motivation

options.label: B
options.text: To create momentum and change what people think is possible

options.label: C
options.text: To distract from the ultimate goal and create a diversion

options.label: D
options.text: To give up on creating change and accept defeat

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a successful early win mentioned in the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: The solidarity movement in Poland

options.label: B
options.text: The Arab Spring protests

options.label: C
options.text: The U.S. Civil Rights Movement

options.label: D
options.text: The Indian Independence Movement

multiple-choice.question: What is required to achieve an early win?

options.label: A
options.text: Simply protesting and raising awareness

options.label: B
options.text: Pressuring policymakers, using the media, and persuading skeptical neighbors

options.label: C
options.text: Giving up on creating change and accepting defeat

options.label: D
options.text: Focusing on a single issue and ignoring other problems

multiple-choice.question: What is the key to creating lasting positive change, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Protest alone

options.label: B
options.text: Showing up after the protest and participating in the grind

options.label: C
options.text: Relying on leaders and experts to create change

options.label: D
options.text: Giving up on creating change and accepting defeat

title: Self-assembly: The power of organizing the unorganized - Skylar Tibbits

multiple-choice.question: What is self-assembly in the context of biology and chemistry?

options.label: A
options.text: A process where ordered parts are manually assembled into a structure

options.label: B
options.text: A system where unordered parts come together in an organized structure on their own

options.label: C
options.text: A method of reproducing DNA and proteins

options.label: D
options.text: A way of repairing damaged tissues

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following is an example of self-assembly in everyday life?

options.label: A
options.text: Building a house using manual labor

options.label: B
options.text: Creating a snowflake

options.label: C
options.text: Assembling a piece of furniture

options.label: D
options.text: Writing a computer program

multiple-choice.question: What determines the 3-D structure of a protein?

options.label: A
options.text: The sequence of amino acids along the chain

options.label: B
options.text: The relationship between the chain and the environment

options.label: C
options.text: Both A and B

options.label: D
options.text: Neither A nor B

multiple-choice.question: What is a characteristic of viruses in terms of self-assembly?

options.label: A
options.text: They are made up of a single unit with a specific shape

options.label: B
options.text: They are made up of a series of sub-units with specific shapes that fit together in precise ways

options.label: C
options.text: They are made up of a series of sub-units with random shapes

options.label: D
options.text: They are made up of a single unit with a random shape

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential application of self-assembly in technology?

options.label: A
options.text: Creating molecular microchips for computers

options.label: B
options.text: Building larger and more complex machines

options.label: C
options.text: Developing new fossil fuels

options.label: D
options.text: Improving traditional manufacturing methods

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a potential use of self-assembly in medicine?

options.label: A
options.text: Creating capsules that can deliver drugs inside the body and release them only under certain conditions

options.label: B
options.text: Developing new surgical techniques

options.label: C
options.text: Improving diagnostic tools

options.label: D
options.text: Creating new vaccines

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential benefit of using self-assembly in construction?

options.label: A
options.text: Buildings can be made larger and more complex

options.label: B
options.text: Buildings can adapt on their own to environmental or dynamic loading

options.label: C
options.text: Buildings can be made more energy-efficient

options.label: D
options.text: Buildings can be constructed more quickly

multiple-choice.question: What is a characteristic of self-assembly that makes it useful for creating complex structures?

options.label: A
options.text: It requires manual labor to assemble the parts

options.label: B
options.text: It allows for precise control over the assembly process

options.label: C
options.text: It enables the creation of complex structures without the need for manual assembly

options.label: D
options.text: It is limited to creating simple structures

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a potential use of self-assembly in space exploration?

options.label: A
options.text: Creating space structures that can self-assemble without humans

options.label: B
options.text: Developing new propulsion systems

options.label: C
options.text: Improving communication systems

options.label: D
options.text: Creating new life support systems

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential benefit of using self-assembly in manufacturing?

options.label: A
options.text: It can make products more expensive and less efficient

options.label: B
options.text: It can make products more adaptive and less reliant on fossil fuels

options.label: C
options.text: It can make products more complex and difficult to assemble

options.label: D
options.text: It can make products more prone to errors and defects

multiple-choice.question: What is the benefit of having a cognitively diverse team when it comes to tasks like problem-solving and coming up with creative ideas?

options.label: A
options.text: It leads to a decrease in collective intelligence

options.label: B
options.text: It results in a limited number of useful ideas

options.label: C
options.text: It provides a massive uplift in collective intelligence

options.label: D
options.text: It has no impact on collective intelligence

multiple-choice.question: If a team of 10 people, each of whom comes up with 10 genuinely useful ideas, are cognitively homogeneous, how many useful ideas do they have in total?
What happens when people are surrounded by others who think like them?

options.label: A
options.text: They become less confident in their solutions

options.label: B
options.text: They are more likely to come up with diverse ideas

options.label: C
options.text: The pleasure centers of their brains light up, and they feel smarter

options.label: D
options.text: They become more open-minded to opposing views

multiple-choice.question: Why do people tend to surround themselves with like-minded others?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it leads to a higher collective intelligence

options.label: B
options.text: Because it allows them to come up with more diverse ideas

options.label: C
options.text: Because it validates their worldview and makes them feel smarter

options.label: D
options.text: Because it leads to better decision-making

multiple-choice.question: What is the problem with surrounding oneself with like-minded others when dealing with complex tasks?

options.label: A
options.text: It leads to a higher collective intelligence

options.label: B
options.text: It results in a limited number of useful ideas

options.label: C
options.text: It provides no uplift in collective intelligence

options.label: D
options.text: It leads to better decision-making

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what will be the key feature of competitive advantage for the next 50 years?

options.label: A
options.text: Cognitive homogeneity

options.label: B
options.text: Surrounding oneself with like-minded others

options.label: C
options.text: Cognitive diversity

options.label: D
options.text: Collective intelligence

multiple-choice.question: Why does the eminent economic forecaster believe that he should work with people who think like him?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it leads to a higher collective intelligence

options.label: B
options.text: Because it allows him to come up with more diverse ideas

options.label: C
options.text: Because he believes his model is the best one out there

options.label: D
options.text: Because it leads to better decision-making

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the problem with the economic forecaster's logic?

options.label: A
options.text: It is too focused on collective intelligence

options.label: B
options.text: It is too focused on cognitive diversity

options.label: C
options.text: It is spectacularly wrong

options.label: D
options.text: It is too narrow-minded

multiple-choice.question: What happens when people mirror each other's perspectives?

options.label: A
options.text: They become less confident in their solutions

options.label: B
options.text: They are more likely to come up with diverse ideas

options.label: C
options.text: They become more confident about a solution that might be gravely mistaken

options.label: D
options.text: They become more open-minded to opposing views

multiple-choice.question: What is the benefit of cognitive diversity in the context of innovation?

options.label: A
options.text: It leads to a decrease in collective intelligence

options.label: B
options.text: It results in a limited number of useful ideas

options.label: C
options.text: It provides a massive uplift in collective intelligence

options.label: D
options.text: It has no impact on collective intelligence
